What is the Hedera JSON-RPC Relay?

The Hedera JSON-RPC Relay is an implementation of Ethereum JSON-RPC APIs for the Hedera network. It utilizes both Hedera Consensus Nodes and Mirror Nodes to support RPC queries defined in the JSON-RPC Specification.

What is Hardhat and how does it relate to the Hedera network?

Hardhat is a development environment for Ethereum, consisting of different components for editing, compiling, debugging, and deploying smart contracts and dApps. In the context of the Hedera network, Hardhat can be used to deploy smart contracts and interact with the network using the Hedera JSON-RPC Relay.

What are the prerequisites for deploying smart contracts using Hardhat and Hedera JSON-RPC Relay?
The prerequisites include a basic understanding of smart contracts, Node.js, JavaScript, and familiarity with the Hardhat Ethereum Development Tool.

How can I set up a project to deploy smart contracts using Hardhat and Hedera JSON-RPC Relay?

To set up a project, you can clone the `hedera-hardhat-example-project` repository, navigate to the preferred directory in the terminal, and run `npm install` to install the dependencies. The project structure includes `contracts`, `scripts`, `test`, `.env.example`, `hardhat.config.js`, `package-lock.json`, and `package.json`. After setting up the project, you can review the project contents for more information.

What are the steps to deploy a smart contract using Hardhat and Hedera JSON-RPC Relay?

The steps include setting up the project, configuring environment variables and the Hardhat configuration file, compiling the smart contract, and testing and deploying the contract to the Hedera network or a local node.

In which networks can I deploy my smart contract using Hardhat and Hedera JSON-RPC Relay?

You can deploy your smart contract using the default network specified in the configuration file, such as the local network or the testnet. Additionally, you can target any network configured in the Hardhat config file for deployment.

What are the additional steps required for deploying on a local node?

Before deploying on a local node, ensure that you have a Hedera Local Node set up and running. You should have two terminals open - one for each of the project directories - `hedera-local-node` and `hedera-hardhat-example-project`. Additionally, Docker should be running and your local node should be started using the command `hedera start -d` in the `hedera-local-node` terminal.

How can I verify my deployed smart contract on the Hedera testnet?

You can verify your deployed smart contract on the Hedera testnet by using a supported Hedera Network Explorer, such as the HashScan Network Explorer. Additionally, you can use the HashScan verification feature (beta) to verify your contract. Make sure to switch the network to TESTNET at the top of the explorer page before searching for the contract.
